trans-unit.source: Create an ASP.NET 5 web app in Visual Studio Code
trans-unit.target: Create an ASP.NET 5 web app in Visual Studio Code

trans-unit.source: This tutorial illustrates how to create an ASP.NET 5 web app using Visual Studio Code.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial illustrates how to create an ASP.NET 5 web app using Visual Studio Code.

trans-unit.source: Create an ASP.NET 5 web app in Visual Studio Code
trans-unit.target: Create an ASP.NET 5 web app in Visual Studio Code

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to create an ASP.NET 5 web app using [Visual Studio Code (VS Code)](http://code.visualstudio.com//Docs/whyvscode) and deploy it to [Azure App Service](../app-service/app-service-value-prop-what-is.md).
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to create an ASP.NET 5 web app using [Visual Studio Code (VS Code)](http://code.visualstudio.com//Docs/whyvscode) and deploy it to [Azure App Service](../app-service/app-service-value-prop-what-is.md).

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET 5 is a significant redesign of ASP.NET.
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET 5 is a significant redesign of ASP.NET.

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET 5 is a new open-source and cross-platform framework for building modern cloud-based web apps using .NET.
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET 5 is a new open-source and cross-platform framework for building modern cloud-based web apps using .NET.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Introduction to ASP.NET 5](http://docs.asp.net/en/latest/conceptual-overview/aspnet.html).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Introduction to ASP.NET 5](http://docs.asp.net/en/latest/conceptual-overview/aspnet.html).

trans-unit.source: For information about Azure App Service web apps, see [Web Apps Overview](app-service-web-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: For information about Azure App Service web apps, see [Web Apps Overview](app-service-web-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Install [VS Code](http://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/setup).
trans-unit.target: Install [VS Code](http://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/setup).

trans-unit.source: Install [Node.js](http://nodejs.org/download/) - [Node.js](http://nodejs.org/) is a platform for building fast and scalable server applications using JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: Install [Node.js](http://nodejs.org/download/) - [Node.js](http://nodejs.org/) is a platform for building fast and scalable server applications using JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: Node is the runtime (Node), and [npm](http://www.npmjs.com/) is the Package Manager for Node modules.
trans-unit.target: Node is the runtime (Node), and [npm](http://www.npmjs.com/) is the Package Manager for Node modules.

trans-unit.source: You will use npm to scaffold an ASP.NET 5 web app in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You will use npm to scaffold an ASP.NET 5 web app in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Install Git - You can install it from either of these locations: [Chocolatey](https://chocolatey.org/packages/git) or [git-scm.com](http://git-scm.com/downloads).
trans-unit.target: Install Git - You can install it from either of these locations: [Chocolatey](https://chocolatey.org/packages/git) or [git-scm.com](http://git-scm.com/downloads).

trans-unit.source: If you are new to Git, choose [git-scm.com](http://git-scm.com/downloads) and select the option to use Git with GitBash and from the Windows command prompt.
trans-unit.target: If you are new to Git, choose [git-scm.com](http://git-scm.com/downloads) and select the option to use Git with GitBash and from the Windows command prompt.

trans-unit.source: Once you install Git, you'll also need to set the Git user name and email as it's required later in the tutorial (when performing a commit from VS Code).
trans-unit.target: Once you install Git, you'll also need to set the Git user name and email as it's required later in the tutorial (when performing a commit from VS Code).

trans-unit.source: Install ASP.NET 5 and DNX
trans-unit.target: Install ASP.NET 5 and DNX

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET 5/DNX is a lean .NET stack for building modern cloud and web apps that run on OS X, Linux, and Windows.
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET 5/DNX is a lean .NET stack for building modern cloud and web apps that run on OS X, Linux, and Windows.

trans-unit.source: It has been built from the ground up to provide an optimized development framework for apps that are either deployed to the cloud or run on-premises.
trans-unit.target: It has been built from the ground up to provide an optimized development framework for apps that are either deployed to the cloud or run on-premises.

trans-unit.source: It consists of modular components with minimal overhead, so you retain flexibility while constructing your solutions.
trans-unit.target: It consists of modular components with minimal overhead, so you retain flexibility while constructing your solutions.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] ASP.NET 5 and DNX (the .NET Execution Environment) on OS X and Linux are in an early Beta/Preview state.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] ASP.NET 5 and DNX (the .NET Execution Environment) on OS X and Linux are in an early Beta/Preview state.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is designed to get you started building applications with the latest development versions of ASP.NET 5 and DNX.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is designed to get you started building applications with the latest development versions of ASP.NET 5 and DNX.

trans-unit.source: The following instructions are specific to Windows.
trans-unit.target: The following instructions are specific to Windows.

trans-unit.source: For more detailed installation instructions for OS X, Linux, and Windows, see [Installing ASP.NET 5 and DNX](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/ASPnet5#_installing-aspnet-5-and-dnx).
trans-unit.target: For more detailed installation instructions for OS X, Linux, and Windows, see [Installing ASP.NET 5 and DNX](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/ASPnet5#_installing-aspnet-5-and-dnx).

trans-unit.source: To install .NET Version Manager (DNVM) in Windows, open a command prompt, and run the following command.
trans-unit.target: To install .NET Version Manager (DNVM) in Windows, open a command prompt, and run the following command.

trans-unit.source: This will download the DNVM script and put it in your user profile directory.
trans-unit.target: This will download the DNVM script and put it in your user profile directory.

trans-unit.source: Restart Windows to complete the DNVM installation.
trans-unit.target: Restart Windows to complete the DNVM installation.

trans-unit.source: Open a command prompt and verify the location of DNVM by entering the following.
trans-unit.target: Open a command prompt and verify the location of DNVM by entering the following.

trans-unit.source: The command prompt will show a path similar to the following.
trans-unit.target: The command prompt will show a path similar to the following.

trans-unit.source: dnvm location
trans-unit.target: dnvm location

trans-unit.source: Now that you have DNVM, you need to use it to download DNX to run your applications.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have DNVM, you need to use it to download DNX to run your applications.

trans-unit.source: Run the following at the command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Run the following at the command prompt.

trans-unit.source: Verify your DNVM, and view the active runtime by entering the following at the command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Verify your DNVM, and view the active runtime by entering the following at the command prompt.

trans-unit.source: The command prompt will show the details of the active runtime.
trans-unit.target: The command prompt will show the details of the active runtime.

trans-unit.source: DNVM location
trans-unit.target: DNVM location

trans-unit.source: If more than one DNX runtime is listed, enter the following at the command prompt to set the active DNX runtime to the same version as the one that is used by the ASP.NET 5 generator when you create your web app later in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: If more than one DNX runtime is listed, enter the following at the command prompt to set the active DNX runtime to the same version as the one that is used by the ASP.NET 5 generator when you create your web app later in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] For more detailed installation instructions for OS X, Linux, and Windows, see [Installing ASP.NET 5 and DNX](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/ASPnet5#_installing-aspnet-5-and-dnx).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] For more detailed installation instructions for OS X, Linux, and Windows, see [Installing ASP.NET 5 and DNX](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/ASPnet5#_installing-aspnet-5-and-dnx).

trans-unit.source: Create the web app
trans-unit.target: Create the web app

trans-unit.source: This section shows you how to scaffold a new app ASP.NET web app.
trans-unit.target: This section shows you how to scaffold a new app ASP.NET web app.

trans-unit.source: You will use the node package manager (npm) to install [Yeoman](http://yeoman.io/) (application scaffolding tool - the VS Code equivalent of the Visual Studio **File > New Project** operation), [Grunt](http://gruntjs.com/) (JavaScript task runner), and [Bower](http://bower.io/) (client side package manager).
trans-unit.target: You will use the node package manager (npm) to install [Yeoman](http://yeoman.io/) (application scaffolding tool - the VS Code equivalent of the Visual Studio **File > New Project** operation), [Grunt](http://gruntjs.com/) (JavaScript task runner), and [Bower](http://bower.io/) (client side package manager).

trans-unit.source: Open a command prompt with Administrator rights and navigate to the location where you want to create your ASP.NET project.
trans-unit.target: Open a command prompt with Administrator rights and navigate to the location where you want to create your ASP.NET project.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following at the command prompt to install Yeoman and the supporting tools.
trans-unit.target: Enter the following at the command prompt to install Yeoman and the supporting tools.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following at the command prompt to create the project folder and scaffold the app.
trans-unit.target: Enter the following at the command prompt to create the project folder and scaffold the app.

trans-unit.source: Use the arrow keys to select the **Web Application** type from the ASP.NET 5 generator menu, and press <Enter>.
trans-unit.target: Use the arrow keys to select the **Web Application** type from the ASP.NET 5 generator menu, and press <Enter>.

trans-unit.source: Yeoman - ASP.NET 5 generator
trans-unit.target: Yeoman - ASP.NET 5 generator

trans-unit.source: Set the name of your new ASP.NET web app to **SampleWebApp**.
trans-unit.target: Set the name of your new ASP.NET web app to **SampleWebApp**.

trans-unit.source: As this name is used throughout the tutorial, if you select a different name, you'll need to substitute it for each occurrence of **SampleWebApp**.
trans-unit.target: As this name is used throughout the tutorial, if you select a different name, you'll need to substitute it for each occurrence of **SampleWebApp**.

trans-unit.source: When you press <Enter>, Yeoman will create a new folder named **SampleWebApp** and the necessary files for your new app.
trans-unit.target: When you press <Enter>, Yeoman will create a new folder named **SampleWebApp** and the necessary files for your new app.

trans-unit.source: Open VS Code by entering the following at the command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Open VS Code by entering the following at the command prompt.

trans-unit.source: In VS Code, select **File > Open Folder**, and select the folder containing your ASP.NET web app.
trans-unit.target: In VS Code, select **File > Open Folder**, and select the folder containing your ASP.NET web app.

trans-unit.source: Select Folder dialog box
trans-unit.target: Select Folder dialog box

trans-unit.source: VS Code will load your project, and display its files in the **Explore** windows.
trans-unit.target: VS Code will load your project, and display its files in the **Explore** windows.

trans-unit.source: VSCode displaying SampleWebApp project
trans-unit.target: VSCode displaying SampleWebApp project

trans-unit.source: Select **View > Command Palette**.
trans-unit.target: Select **View > Command Palette**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Command Palette**, enter the following commands.
trans-unit.target: In the **Command Palette**, enter the following commands.

trans-unit.source: As you start typing, you will see the full command line from the list.
trans-unit.target: As you start typing, you will see the full command line from the list.

trans-unit.source: Restore command
trans-unit.target: Restore command

trans-unit.source: The Restore command installs the necessary NuGet packages to run the application.
trans-unit.target: The Restore command installs the necessary NuGet packages to run the application.

trans-unit.source: A command prompt will display **Restore complete** when ready.
trans-unit.target: A command prompt will display **Restore complete** when ready.

trans-unit.source: Run the web app locally
trans-unit.target: Run the web app locally

trans-unit.source: Now that you have created the web app and retrieved all the NuGet packages for the app, you can run the web app locally.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have created the web app and retrieved all the NuGet packages for the app, you can run the web app locally.

trans-unit.source: From the **Command Palette** in VS Code, enter the following to run the app locally.
trans-unit.target: From the **Command Palette** in VS Code, enter the following to run the app locally.

trans-unit.source: The command window will display *Started* in it.
trans-unit.target: The command window will display *Started* in it.

trans-unit.source: If the command window doesn't display *Started*, check the lower left corning of VS Code for errors in your project.
trans-unit.target: If the command window doesn't display *Started*, check the lower left corning of VS Code for errors in your project.

trans-unit.source: Open a browser and navigate to the following URL.
trans-unit.target: Open a browser and navigate to the following URL.

trans-unit.source: http://localhost:5001
trans-unit.target: http://localhost:5001

trans-unit.source: The default page of the web app will appear as follows.
trans-unit.target: The default page of the web app will appear as follows.

trans-unit.source: Local web app in a browser
trans-unit.target: Local web app in a browser

trans-unit.source: Create a web app in the Azure preview portal
trans-unit.target: Create a web app in the Azure preview portal

trans-unit.source: The following steps will guide you through creating a web app in the Azure preview portal.
trans-unit.target: The following steps will guide you through creating a web app in the Azure preview portal.

trans-unit.source: Log in to the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com).
trans-unit.target: Log in to the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com).

trans-unit.source: Click **NEW** at the top left of the portal.
trans-unit.target: Click **NEW** at the top left of the portal.

trans-unit.source: Click **Web Apps > Web App**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Web Apps > Web App**.

trans-unit.source: Azure new web app
trans-unit.target: Azure new web app

trans-unit.source: Enter a value for **Name**, such as **SampleWebAppDemo**.
trans-unit.target: Enter a value for **Name**, such as **SampleWebAppDemo**.

trans-unit.source: Note that this name needs to be unique, and the portal will enforce that when you attempt to enter the name.
trans-unit.target: Note that this name needs to be unique, and the portal will enforce that when you attempt to enter the name.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, if you select a enter a different value, you'll need to substitute that value for each occurrence of **SampleWebAppDemo** that you see in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, if you select a enter a different value, you'll need to substitute that value for each occurrence of **SampleWebAppDemo** that you see in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Select an existing **App Service Plan** or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: Select an existing **App Service Plan** or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: If you create a new plan, select the pricing tier, location, and other options.
trans-unit.target: If you create a new plan, select the pricing tier, location, and other options.

trans-unit.source: For more information on App Service plans, see the article, [Azure App Service plans in-depth overview](../app-service/azure-web-sites-web-hosting-plans-in-depth-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information on App Service plans, see the article, [Azure App Service plans in-depth overview](../app-service/azure-web-sites-web-hosting-plans-in-depth-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: Azure new web app blade
trans-unit.target: Azure new web app blade

trans-unit.source: Click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: web app blade
trans-unit.target: web app blade

trans-unit.source: Enable Git publishing for the new web app
trans-unit.target: Enable Git publishing for the new web app

trans-unit.source: Git is a distributed version control system that you can use to deploy your Azure App Service web app.
trans-unit.target: Git is a distributed version control system that you can use to deploy your Azure App Service web app.

trans-unit.source: You'll store the code you write for your web app in a local Git repository, and you'll deploy your code to Azure by pushing to a remote repository.
trans-unit.target: You'll store the code you write for your web app in a local Git repository, and you'll deploy your code to Azure by pushing to a remote repository.

trans-unit.source: Log into the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com).
trans-unit.target: Log into the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com).

trans-unit.source: Click **Browse All**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Browse All**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Web Apps** to view a list of the web apps associated with your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Click **Web Apps** to view a list of the web apps associated with your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Select the web app you created in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Select the web app you created in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In the web app blade, scroll down to locate the **Deployment** section, and click **Set up continuous deployment**.
trans-unit.target: In the web app blade, scroll down to locate the **Deployment** section, and click **Set up continuous deployment**.

trans-unit.source: Azure web app host
trans-unit.target: Azure web app host

trans-unit.source: Click **Choose Source > Local Git Repository**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Choose Source > Local Git Repository**.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Azure Local Git Respository
trans-unit.target: Azure Local Git Respository

trans-unit.source: If you have not previously set up deployment credentials for publishing a web app or other App Service app, set them up now:
trans-unit.target: If you have not previously set up deployment credentials for publishing a web app or other App Service app, set them up now:

trans-unit.source: Click **FTP** to set deployment credentials.
trans-unit.target: Click **FTP** to set deployment credentials.

trans-unit.source: Create a user name and password.
trans-unit.target: Create a user name and password.

trans-unit.source: You'll need this password later when setting up Git.
trans-unit.target: You'll need this password later when setting up Git.

trans-unit.source: Click **Save**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Save**.

trans-unit.source: Azure Deployment Credentials
trans-unit.target: Azure Deployment Credentials

trans-unit.source: In your web app's blade, click **Settings > Properties**.
trans-unit.target: In your web app's blade, click **Settings > Properties**.

trans-unit.source: The URL of the remote Git repository that you'll deploy to is shown under **
trans-unit.target: The URL of the remote Git repository that you'll deploy to is shown under **

trans-unit.source: URL**.
trans-unit.target: URL**.

trans-unit.source: Copy the **GIT URL** value for later use in the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Copy the **GIT URL** value for later use in the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Azure Git URL
trans-unit.target: Azure Git URL

trans-unit.source: Publish your web app to Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Publish your web app to Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will create a local Git repository and push from that repository to Azure to deploy your web app to Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will create a local Git repository and push from that repository to Azure to deploy your web app to Azure.

trans-unit.source: In VS Code, select the **Git** option in the left navigation bar.
trans-unit.target: In VS Code, select the **Git** option in the left navigation bar.

trans-unit.source: Git icon in VS Code
trans-unit.target: Git icon in VS Code

trans-unit.source: Select **Initialize git repository** to make sure your workspace is under git source control.
trans-unit.target: Select **Initialize git repository** to make sure your workspace is under git source control.

trans-unit.source: Initialize Git
trans-unit.target: Initialize Git

trans-unit.source: Add a commit message and click the **Commit All** check icon.
trans-unit.target: Add a commit message and click the **Commit All** check icon.

trans-unit.source: Git Commit All
trans-unit.target: Git Commit All

trans-unit.source: After Git has completed processing, you'll see that there are no files listed in the Git window under **Changes**.
trans-unit.target: After Git has completed processing, you'll see that there are no files listed in the Git window under **Changes**.

trans-unit.source: Git no changes
trans-unit.target: Git no changes

trans-unit.source: Open a command prompt, and change directories to the directory housing your web app.
trans-unit.target: Open a command prompt, and change directories to the directory housing your web app.

trans-unit.source: Create a remote reference for pushing updates to your web app by using the Git URL (ending in ".git") that you copied earlier.
trans-unit.target: Create a remote reference for pushing updates to your web app by using the Git URL (ending in ".git") that you copied earlier.

trans-unit.source: Configure Git to save your credentials locally so that they will be automatically appended to your push commands generated from VS Code.
trans-unit.target: Configure Git to save your credentials locally so that they will be automatically appended to your push commands generated from VS Code.

trans-unit.source: Push your changes to Azure by entering the following command.
trans-unit.target: Push your changes to Azure by entering the following command.

trans-unit.source: After this initial push to Azure, you will be able to do all the push commands from VS Code.
trans-unit.target: After this initial push to Azure, you will be able to do all the push commands from VS Code.

trans-unit.source: You are prompted for the password you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: You are prompted for the password you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: Note: Your password will not be visible.
trans-unit.target: Note: Your password will not be visible.

trans-unit.source: The output from the above command ends with a message that deployment is successful.
trans-unit.target: The output from the above command ends with a message that deployment is successful.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you make changes to your app, you can republish directly in VS Code using the built-in Git functionality by selecting the **Commit All** option followed by the **Push** option.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you make changes to your app, you can republish directly in VS Code using the built-in Git functionality by selecting the **Commit All** option followed by the **Push** option.

trans-unit.source: You will find the **Push** option available in the drop-down menu next to the **Commit All** and **Refresh** buttons.
trans-unit.target: You will find the **Push** option available in the drop-down menu next to the **Commit All** and **Refresh** buttons.

trans-unit.source: If you need to collaborate on a project, you should consider pushing to GitHub in between pushing to Azure.
trans-unit.target: If you need to collaborate on a project, you should consider pushing to GitHub in between pushing to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Run the app in Azure
trans-unit.target: Run the app in Azure

trans-unit.source: Now that you have deployed your web app, let's run the app while hosted in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have deployed your web app, let's run the app while hosted in Azure.

trans-unit.source: This can be done in two ways:
trans-unit.target: This can be done in two ways:

trans-unit.source: Open a browser and enter the name of your web app as follows.
trans-unit.target: Open a browser and enter the name of your web app as follows.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, locate the web app blade for your web app, and click **Browse** to view your app in your default browser.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, locate the web app blade for your web app, and click **Browse** to view your app in your default browser.

trans-unit.source: Azure web app
trans-unit.target: Azure web app

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you learned how to create a web app in VS Code and deploy it to Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you learned how to create a web app in VS Code and deploy it to Azure.

trans-unit.source: For more information about VS Code, see the article, [Why Visual Studio Code?](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/).
trans-unit.target: For more information about VS Code, see the article, [Why Visual Studio Code?](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/).

trans-unit.source: For information about App Service web apps, see [Web Apps Overview](app-service-web-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: For information about App Service web apps, see [Web Apps Overview](app-service-web-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
